Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop, NSF Cloud for Everyone, will develop curricula, course materials, and projects, for the use of the NSF Cloud facilities CloudLab and Chameleon in graduate and advanced undergraduate systems courses at institutions serving under served populations, specifically Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs) and Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). The Workshop will feature tutorials to train faculty at the target institutions on the use of CloudLab and Chameleon, and then will consist of collaborative interactive sessions to adapt existing course material to use Chameleon and CloudLab and develop new assignments and research projects that use these facilities.

Intellectual Merit: This workshop will develop new course materials for graduate and advanced undergraduate courses in Cloud computing, particularly the design and implementation of Clouds. Though targeted at specific institutions, these materials will be broadly usable by undergraduate and graduate classes throughout the United States. This Workshop will also demonstrate joint project across both facilities.

Broader Impacts: The primary impact will be the enhanced education of underserved communities. Workshop participants have in identified specific classes at their institutions which will feature these facilities. This also has the effect of enhanced workforce training, both for commercial Cloud ventures and for the undergraduate and graduate research population. Workshop participants will form the nucleus of a Cloud Education community going forward, since we will make results public and maintain the community as a mutual-support organization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Held on November 10 and 11, 2016, the NSF Cloud For Everyone Workshop held in Atlanta, Georgia was a first step in making the NSF Cloud Facilities, CloudLab (http://cloudlab.us) and Chameleon (http://www.chameleoncloud.org), a tool for classroom and laboratory use in undergraduate classrooms at institutions that serve underserved populations.  Over 25 faculty members, primarily from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) and Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSIs) attended the workshop, which featured hands-on training on these facilities and the formation of focus groups to adapt these facilities for courses most important to undergraduate education.

 

The view of the Workshop participants, and the driving motivation behind the cloud-educators organization formed at the workshop, is that the NSF Cloud facilities  are large scale laboratories  which are potentially available to every higher education institution, student, and researcher across the United States.  This has the potential to offer new possibilities for undergraduate education, and the goal of the Workshop and the cloud-educators organization is to develop the syllabi and materials to bring this to every undergraduate in the United States.

 

Workshop Results

The cloud-educators Google Group was created as a post-workshop mailing list for attendees and others interested in the activities.

The Cloud Educators Github organization was created and granted educational status to permit unlimited public and private repositories.  This will be used for  Slides, elab workbooks, software, papers, and assignments.  Dirk Grunwald (U Colorado) and Carlos Maltzahn (CROSS, UC Santa Cruz) will maintain the repository.

Nine (9) instructors committed to using CloudLab and Chameleon in courses in 2017:

   Course               Institution               Instructor                  Date               Area/Description

    CSC280        Fayetteville            Akpabio Akpabio            Spring 2017            Cybersecurity

    CS 401          Talladega            Daniel Okunbor            Spring 2017            Cybersecurity

    TCSS 562       UW Tacoma            Wesley Lloyd            Fall 2017            Software Engineering for Clouds

    CIIC 4019       UPR Mayaguez            Wilson Rivera            Fall 2017            High-Performance Computing

 

Seven (7) working groups were formed to address Cybersecurity, Parallel Programming/Scientific Computing, Operating Systems, Cloud Systems and Applications, Tools/Encapsulation, Software/Repositories, Certifications
